Understand the patterns and drivers of forest mortality, across a range of spatial scales and ecosystem types

Current and anticipated climate extremes such as drought, heatwaves, and wildfire pose fundamental threats to forest sustainability and the vital services they provide to human society. Widespread forest mortality has been observed across the globe and accurate predictions of forest mortality in response to global environment change are critical for effective conservation. However, our current predictive capacity of observed forest die-off remains limited. Broadly, forest mortality can be influenced by the combination of climatic stress, topography, forest stand properties, and biotic agents such as insects and pathogens. Various studies have examined how these factors could impact forest die-off patterns, but the results appeared to vary substantially by individual studies that looked at different regions and/or used disparate datasets and methods. This line of research aims to combine multiple data streams of mortality observations, mechanistic modeling, and remotely sensed ecosystem resilience to gain holistic understandings of the patterns and drivers of forest mortality. In particular, I am interested in how plant hydraulics and functional traits co-evolve with their micro-environments and combine to influence their mortality during climate extreme events. Further, while broad climate variations can be quantified using standardized approaches, the heterogeneities of micro-environment within the same or similar climate regimes and their roles on forest mortality are less well characterized and understood. We are working to develop an integrated analytic framework across a wide range of ecosystems to reconcile currently conflicting findings about the drivers and mechanisms underlying forest mortality, leveraging continental mortality observations from Forest Inventory Analysis (FIA) and Aerial Detection Surveys (ADS).
